I have personal reasons why I don't automatically "believe women." In 2006 while I was still in college, I witnessed a physical altercation between a couple. The man slapped the woman harder than I've ever seen anyone slapped in my life, and then he walked away.  He slapped her so hard she fell and skinned her knee.  When he was gone I am very cautiously approached her and asked if she needed help. I didn't try to touch her, I really didn't get close to her, I just knelt and asked her if she needed help or needed me to call the campus police.  She looked at me with absolute venom and said that if I didn't get away from her, she would start screaming and tell the police that I was the one that hit her.  And then she did scream.  14 years later, I can still recall the sharp tone in her voice when she said "I'll tell the police YOU did this!"

Me.  Not her boyfriend who slapped the living shit out of her, so hard I'm surprised she didn't get whiplash, but me. An innocent bystander who offered to help.  And just like that, my view of women changed irrevocably.  And this was 11 years before MeToo.

Now, this doesn't mean that when I hear an abuse accusation I automatically DISbelieve women and think they're all lying.  But I am never going to automatically believe anyone. I believe evidence instead.  To automatically believe them just invites anyone to take advantage of how naive you are.
